Electron-Photon Interactions

  • With low light intensities, photons may probe the quantum ground and excited states of solids. In this (weak-coupling) regime, it can be assumed that the transitions do not modify the quantum states themselves.
  • In the strong light intensity (strong-coupling) regime, the strength of the electric field incoming radiation becomes comparable with the electric field between electrons and ions in the crystal.
    • Here, we expect quantum states of the solid to be modified, leading to a regime where non-linear optical effects occur.

      • Assuming that Ec(k⃗)−Ev(k⃗)=Eg+ℏ2k22me∗+ℏ2k22mh∗E_c(\vec k)-E_v(\vec k)=E_g+\frac{\hbar^2k^2}{2m_e^*}+\frac{\hbar^2 k^2}{2m_h^*}Ec​(k)−Ev​(k)=Eg​+2me∗​ℏ2k2​+2mh∗​ℏ2k2​﻿ in a semiconductor, the JDOS between a parabolic valence band maximum and a parabolic conduction minimum is the 3D density of states (could also derive it the way done last year);
    • It is apparent from the above that JDOS is dominated by points where the valence and conduction bands are parallel; ∇k⃗(Ec(k⃗)−Ev(k⃗))=0\nabla{\vec k}(E_c(\vec k)-E_v(\vec k))=0∇k(Ec​(k)−Ev​(k))=0﻿.
      • These are critical points, which lead to Van-Hove singularities.
      • At these points, band separation energy may be written in terms of three orthogonal k-space coordinates, forming quadric surfaces;
      • In 3D there are four types of critical points corresponding to the number of negative coefficients αi\alpha_iαi​﻿.
        • M0M_0M0​﻿ is a minimum in Eb(k)E_b(k)Eb​(k)﻿, where all three αi\alpha_iαi​﻿ are positive - ellipsoidal.
        • M1/M2M_1/M_2M1​/M2​﻿ are two types of saddle point in Eb(k)E_b(k)Eb​(k)﻿, where one or two αi\alpha_iαi​﻿ are negative - hyperboloids.
        • M3M_3M3​﻿ is a maximum in Eb(k)E_b(k)Eb​(k)﻿ where all three αi\alpha_iαi​﻿ are negative -? said in lecture.
      • Each type of critical point has a characteristic frequency dependence of the JDOS near the critical point. The Van-Hove singularities are also sharper in one and two dimensions.

Indirect Bandgap Semiconductors

  • In an indirect bandgap semiconductor, the minimum of the conduction band is at a different position in the Brillouin zone than the maximum of the valence band. Hence, a phonon is required for an optical transition in order to conserve momentum.
    • This can occur either via phonon emission or absorption. The absorption coefficient is then
    • Here, EphE_{ph}Eph​﻿ is the energy of the phonon involved in the transition, EigE_{ig}Eig​﻿ is the energy of the indirect bandgap, nq=1/(exp⁡(Eph/kBT)−1)n_q=1/(\exp(E_{ph}/k_B T) -1)nq​=1/(exp(Eph​/kB​T)−1)﻿ is the phonon occupation factor (propto probability of phonon absorption), and nq+1=1/(1−exp⁡(Eph/kBT))n_q+1=1/(1-\exp(E_{ph}/k_B T))nq​+1=1/(1−exp(Eph​/kB​T))﻿ is the probability for photon emission from both stimulated and spontaneous emission processes.
    • Plotting α(ω)\sqrt{\alpha(\omega)}α(ω)​﻿ shows an initial straight line where phonon absorption is observed (ℏω≥Eig−Eph\hbar \omega\ge E_{ig}-E_{ph}ℏω≥Eig​−Eph​﻿), before a steeper gradient emerges when the phonon emission process is included at higher energy (ℏω≥Eig+Eph\hbar \omega \ge E_{ig}+E_{ph}ℏω≥Eig​+Eph​﻿).
      • Measuring the absorption spectrum allows for information about the photon spectrum of the crystal to be obtained.
      • Indirect bandgap semiconductors are poor light emitters because indirect emission is slow and competes with non-radiative decay mechanisms. Hence, no silicon lasers.
